answers.text: to coordinate and organize their growth and development

qas.question: How do fungi communicate with insects?
How many primary signalling molecules are known to organize different behavioral patterns?
What enables an organism to differentiate between self and other?
What is an example of "noise" that is filtered out through the interpretation processes?
There are four primary signalling molecules that are known to organize what?
What can't differentiate between molecules taking part in biotic messages or irrelevant messages?
How many secondary signalling molecules are known to coordinate?
What substance always triggers the fungal organism to react the same way every time?

context: Fungi communicate <a0_0>to coordinate and organize their growth and development<a0_0/> such as the formation of Marcelia and fruiting bodies. Fungi communicate with their own and related species as well as with non fungal organisms in a great variety of symbiotic interactions, especially with bacteria, unicellular eukaryote, plants and insects <a1_0>through biochemicals of biotic origin<a1_0/>. The <b8_0>biochemicals<b8_0/> trigger the fungal organism to react in a specific manner, while if the same chemical molecules are not part of biotic messages, they do not trigger the fungal organism to react. This implies that <b6_0>fungal organisms<b6_0/> can differentiate between molecules taking part in biotic messages and similar molecules being irrelevant in the situation. So far <a2_0><b7_0>five<b7_0/><a2_0/> different primary signalling molecules are known to coordinate <b5_0>different behavioral patterns<b5_0/> such as filamentation, mating, growth, and pathogenicity. Behavioral coordination and production of signaling substances is achieved through <a3_0>interpretation processes<a3_0/> that enables the organism to differ between self or non-self, a biotic indicator, biotic message from similar, related, or non-related species, and even filter out "noise", i.e. <a4_0><b9_0>similar molecules without biotic content<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
